title: How to Recycle Concrete

steps.headline: Wear protective eyewear and work gloves.
steps.description: Take the proper safety precautions to keep concrete chips from flying into your eyes. Concrete can also be tough on skin, so invest in a pair of work gloves to protect your skin.

steps.headline: Grab a sledgehammer and a pry bar.
steps.description: Sledgehammers have long handles, which helps protect against concrete chips flying into you. Invest in a sledgehammer that you can lift easily. If your slab of concrete is reinforced with wire mesh, you will need bolt cutters as well. If your slab of concrete is surrounded by ground that can be dug up, grab a shovel as well. Cover the concrete slab with 4-mil thick plastic if working near windows. This will keep the concrete chunks from flying into the windows.

steps.headline: Use a shovel to dig into the dirt under the concrete.
steps.description: Compacted soil surrounding the concrete can increase its stability. If possible, use a shovel to remove the ground around the concrete to make it easier to break. Call 811 to check for underground utilities before you dig.

steps.headline: Break the concrete with a sledgehammer.
steps.description: Start on one corner of the concrete, about 6 inches (15 cm) from the edge, and work your way in. Work on breaking the concrete in small, manageable chunks. Continue until the concrete is completely broken up. To use a sledgehammer, grab the butt end of the handle with your left hand. Hold the handle near the head with your right hand. Raise the sledgehammer up over your right shoulder and drop it down onto the concrete. Let the hammer fall instead of swinging it. Allow gravity to help you. Raise the sledgehammer in a higher arc for a more powerful impact.

steps.headline: Use a pry bar to help break up the concrete.
steps.description: Using a pry bar will help you break up the concrete more quickly. Stick one end of the pry bar underneath the cracked concrete. Pull the handle back toward you to push the bar up and break up the concrete. If you come across any wire mesh as you break up the concrete, use bolt cutters to cut it.

steps.headline: Gather the bigger pieces of concrete.
steps.description: One great way to reuse broken concrete pieces is to build a low retaining wall. This is cheaper than paying for bricks and can add an organic, natural feel to your home or landscaping project. Pick out the pieces that have rough edges and little texture on bottom. The smoother they are on bottom, the easier they will be to stack. Collect pieces that are roughly the same width. A good width is 3–4 inches (7.6–10.2 cm), but you can make your wall thicker or thinner if you choose.

steps.headline: Scope out a flat section of land.
steps.description: Determine where you want to stack your wall. Try to find a plot of land that is as flat as possible. It will be harder to stack the bricks evenly if the land is sloped or bumpy.

steps.headline: Place the concrete pieces in a single, flat layer.
steps.description: Lay them side-by-side so that they’re touching. Make a single layer of concrete bricks, making it as long and wide as you want. Be creative! The concrete pieces will have different edge shapes, so you’ll need to play around with how you want them to lay. Try to keep the layer of concrete bricks a consistent width along the entire length of the wall.

steps.headline: Stack a second layer on top of the first.
steps.description: Follow the same method you used to lay the first layer, but stack a second layer on top of the first. Balance each brick between the two bricks underneath it. Continue stacking until you’ve completely covered the bottom layer.

steps.headline: Continue stacking bricks in the same way.
steps.description: Create similar layers of concrete bricks until the wall is as tall as you want it. You may need to go back and get more concrete, depending on how big your wall is.

methods.name: Lining a Patio or Walking Path

steps.headline: Measure off the area you want to line.
steps.description: You can use old concrete pieces to line patios, walkways, and driveways. To begin, figure out where you want to lay the patio or walkway. Use a tape measure to make sure your area is a consistent length on each side. Use flags or tape to mark the area you will be covering.

steps.headline: Clear the area you just marked.
steps.description: You will need to clear away grass and sod before you can start to lay your concrete pieces. If the ground is covered in grass, use a sod cutter to remove the top 3–4 inches (7.6–10.2 cm) of sod. To use a sod cutter, cut the ground into strips and flip each strip over to reveal the roots. Remove the ground in strips until the area you marked has been completely cleared.

steps.headline: Fill the area you cleared with roughly 1 inch (2.5 cm) of sand.
steps.description: This will create a solid foundation for laying your concrete pieces. You can purchase sand from most local hardware stores.

steps.headline: Place the concrete pieces inside the marked area.
steps.description: Strategically place the concrete chunks in whichever way is visually appealing to you. After you've laid the pieces how you want them, fill the spaces in between the concrete chunks with sand or dirt for a finished, polished look. Be creative with this process! There is no right way to lay the pieces, as it depends entirely upon how you want the final product to look.
